title: Alex Smilor
text:
Hi, my name is Alex Smilor.
I am studying Ecosystem Science at Colorado State University, with a particular interest in avian and forest ecology as that relates to climate and anthropogenic change. I have worked extensively with field methods used in bird and forest monitoring research, ranging from point count surveys of passerines in New Mexico to extensive forest inventory surveys for climate adaptation research projects in Colorado. Additionally, while studying abroad in Ushuaia, Argentina I conducted an independent research project studying how climate change and warming spring temperatures affected the breeding phenology of a small Gentoo Penguin colony.
Beyond this, I love to spend my time outdoors, especially hiking, skiing, biking, and camping. I also spend an arguably excessive amount of time birdwatching in areas around the country and have slowly accumulated a life list exceeding 450 species in the US. I also love to take my many opportunities outside to take images of all of the nature around me, especially birds. Lastly, I participate in a number of citizen science initiatives, including eBird, Christmas Bird Counts, and iNaturalist.

Work Experience







Student Lab Assistant
Colorado Forest Restoration Institute

Updated and modified the organization’s website using Wordpress software to improve the front-end user experience.
Showcased forestry treatment results from mechanical thinning and prescribed burns through the development of a photo series collection demonstrating how plots changed over the course of a few years.

August 2024 – Present


Subalpine Forest Monitoring Field Technician
Colorado Forest Restoration Institute

Worked on CFRI’s Adaptive Silviculture for Climate Change (ASCC) project at State Forest State Park and Spruce Beetle Epidemic and Aspen Decline Management Response (SBEADMR) project in Gunnison National Forest monitoring forest health, regeneration, and stand composition as a part of long-term research projects.
Responsibilities:

Used stem mapping procedures using a variable radius plot protocol
Identified and measured the height and diameter at breast height (DBH) of trees, saplings and seedlings
Navigated using a GPS
Entered data on paper and on an Allegro 2.

Drove a 4-wheel drive vehicle on highways and backcountry dirt roads, camped for up to eight-days at a time, hiked up to four miles round trip to plots often through technically challenging and off-trail terrain, and worked in adverse conditions including rain, hail, thunder, and lightning.
Co-led a crew of four people total and was responsible for ensuring the health and safety of the crew, deciding which plots to prioritize, and helping resolve issues or answer questions as they arose.
Communicated with crew members to work together successfully, adapted to changing conditions and resolved problems using limited resources available.

July 2023 – August 2023


Fire Ecology Field Technician
Department of Forest and Rangeland Stewardship at CSU

Worked on a graduate student project studying the impact of wildfire on avian communities and their habitat associations two decades after fire in the Rocky Mountains of Colorado and northern New Mexico.
Responsibilities:

Conducted avian point count surveys
Identified over 60 Rocky Mountain bird species
Assessed forest composition and inventory

Camped for up to 8 days at a time, hiked up to six miles round trip to a plot through technically challenging and off-trail terrain, and worked in adverse weather conditions including rain, hail, thunder, and high heat.
